title: Drop dependency on twox-hash
body:
twox-hash hasn't been keeping up with the dependency update cycle, and
so brings in an old version of the rand crate. I didn't see a compelling
reason to use XxHash over the default hash algorithm, so just remove it.

title: Optionalize type conversion dependencies
body:
The extensive suite of type conversions is often useful, but not all
downstream users want to take the dependency on all of:

  * bigdecimal
  * chrono
  * rust_decimal
  * time
  * uuid

Having to take a dependency on two separate decimal libraries and two
separate date/time libraries is particularly painful. Mark all the
dependencies as optional, so they can be toggled on and off as users
desire.

For backwards compatibility, the features are all still enabled by
default.

title: Redefine serialization/deserialization
body:
* Introduce MySerialize and MyDeserialize traits;
* Use caller's buffer for serialization.

title: Remove dependency on deprecated `failure` crate
body: The `failure` crate is officially deprecated/unmaintained (see https://rustsec.org/advisories/RUSTSEC-2020-0036.html). This replaces its only use with a manual implementation of the `std::error::Error` trait where necessary.

title: Follow MySQL spec in HandshakeResponse
body: I've noticed that some parts of `HandshakeResponse::new` are not following the MySQL spec, especially around db_name and auth-response: [(spec)](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/internals/en/connection-phase-packets.html#packet-Protocol::HandshakeResponse) I've changed the code to follow the spec and it now works correctly with my MySQL Server 5.7. This is my first PR in Rust, so please let me know if there's room to improve the code. Thanks! @blackbeam

title: Split Value::Float into 32 and 64 bit variants
body:
Casting between f32 and f64 can cause precision loss. I have a minimal reproduction here [in this repo](https://github.com/tomhoule/mysql-async-float-precision-loss-repro). This happens for us when writing and reading from `float4` columns. I haven't been able to find the proper place to test this, so there are no tests, but I manually confirmed that this fixes the issue in our case.

The naming of the variants is just an idea, I chose what rust users are probably most familiar with.

This is a breaking change, but I think it's pretty important to fix.

title: Upgrade `time` to 0.2
body:
Some upgrade notes:

- Replaced `time` 0.1's `impl ConvIr<Timespec> for ParseIr<Timespec>` and `impl From<Timespec> for Value` with `time` 0.2 related structs:
	- `impl ConvIr<OffsetDateTime> for ParseIr<OffsetDateTime>` / `impl From<OffsetDateTime> for Value`
	- `impl ConvIr<PrimitiveDateTime> for ParseIr<PrimitiveDateTime>` / `impl From<PrimitiveDateTime> for Value`
	- `impl ConvIr<Date> for ParseIr<Date>` / `impl From<Date> for Value`
	- `impl ConvIr<Time> for ParseIr<Time>` / `impl From<Time> for Value`
	
- Updated `impl From<time::Duration> for Value` to use `time::Duration`'s new `whole_x` functions.

- `time`'s `Time::parse` will reject any time outside of the 00:00:00-23:59:59 range, whereas MySQL's `TIME` data type works as both time and duration, allowing for -838:59:59 - 838:59:59. As such, I've documented that time's `Time` should only be used when expecting the time to always be within a 24 hour range, or `time::Duration` otherwise.

- Test `parse_mysql_datetime_string_parses_valid_time` doesn't actually generate only valid time. An example of that is `1345-35-86 98:56:69.331` - outside of both `time` and MySQL's valid ranges. Because of this, I didn't implement any logic for `time` related functionality within that test, since `time` will throw an `Err` with those invalid values.

- Added some logic within test `parse_mysql_datetime_string_parses_correctly` to ensure `time` parses valid date/time strings and rejects invalid ones correctly. This is a bit more involved that how `parse_mysql_datetime_string` is tested, as that function simply uses regex to parse values based on what format the string matches and doesn't actually validate if the date/time is valid (as in, `parse_mysql_datetime_string` will return date/time data for a date like February 30th, whereas `parse_mysql_datetime_string_with_time` will return an Err.

- Added benchmarks for `parse_mysql_datetime_string_with_time` and `parse_mysql_time_string_with_time`.

title: Bump dependencies
body: `rand` in particular is nice to keep up with so we don't have to build both `0.6` *and* `0.7` in downstream crates.

title: handshake packet to parse auth plugin name up to first zero byte
body:
I've encountered an issue where mysql_async wasn't able to establish SSL connection with a database, because the name of auth plugin was parsed incorrectly (`UnknownAuthPlugin { name: "mysql_native_password\u{0}" }`). The problem here is that the handshake packet contains two leading zero bytes instead of only one or none. This is the server I've been using: https://github.com/facebook/mysql-5.6 but I am unable to provide detailed configuration for that server nor a repro in a more popular mysql server version.

I've noticed that the https://github.com/mysql/mysql-proxy as well as https://github.com/mysql/mysql-server parses the handshake auth plugin part a bit differently - [the latter](https://github.com/mysql/mysql-server/blob/124c7ab1d6f914637521fd4463a993aa73403513/sql/auth/sql_authentication.cc#L805) is using strcasecmp which compares strings up to the first `\0` and [the former](https://github.com/mysql/mysql-proxy/blob/ca6ad61af9088147a568a079c44d0d322f5bee59/src/network-mysqld-packet.c#L1256) simply looks for the first `\0` in an array of chars.

Both of those approaches work well when two leading zero bytes are send, so I am proposing to fix the mysql_common crate to look for the first `\0` when parsing auth plugin name instead of assuming there is only one or none `\0`.

title: Parse with the lexical crate instead of atoi
body:
The `atoi` crate can't handle negative numbers (see [this comment](https://github.com/pacman82/atoi-rs/blob/master/src/lib.rs#L42-L45) in the documentation), so attempting to use `from_value` or `from_value_opt` on negative numbers results in this:

```rust
> mysql::from_value_opt::<i16>(b"-2"[..].into())
Err(FromValueError(Bytes("-2")))
```

This PR removes the `atoi` crate and replaces it with [`lexical`](https://crates.io/crates/lexical), which correctly handles this case. It also handles parsing `f32` and `f64` from byte slices, so that has been introduced as well.

This passes all test cases locally, but I wasn't able to patch the project I'm using since the `mysql` crate on crates.io isn't compatible with the changes introduced by 4239fc3dea2acd302bb55d89893426a6d657e73f. Some live testing with a server is probably warranted since I touched a few places where `atoi` was being used in packet parsing.
